thread.title: Moir Stakes 2015: Buffering wins record third title
thread.title_full: Moir Stakes 2015: Buffering wins record third title | DailyTelegraph

author: Danny Russell
title: Moir Stakes 2015: Buffering wins record third title
text:
QUEENSLAND champion Buffering continued the spring dominance of the eight-year-old warriors by winning a record third Group 1 Moir Stakes at Moonee Valley on Friday night.
It was trademark Buffering.
He worked like a bulldog to cross to the lead, and then called on his great reserves of courage to hold off Ball of Muscle on the line.
The win takes his career earnings past $5 million. A horse that cost $26,000.
An ecstatic trainer Robert Heathcote said he was never truly confident his champion had fully recovered from a nine-month injury lay-off until jockey Damian Browne drove him past the line.
“He served it up to them,” Heathcote said.
Other Stories Hero took five bullets to stop gunman 0 comments Police building had been ‘cased’ News 0 comments First wife ‘neglected’ by cricket legend Nsw Rochelle’s sad story remains Russell’s agony Sydney Confidential Family horrified by paedo’s history News NSW police worker, gunman shot dead Breaking News “I said to Damian, ‘they are not going to let you cross, but you have just got to keep going’.
“The horse showed his customary fight and tenacity, he kicked on the corner and was too tough.”
Three-year-old filly Petits Filous took a sit behind the leaders but lacked her usual brilliance, finishing at the tail of the field.
Buffering will now head towards the Group 1 Manikato Stakes on Cox Plate eve.
Jockey Damian Browne and trainer Robert Heathcote celebrate Buffering’s win. Sydney jockey Blake Shinn had a special moment on a long day, winning the 1600m Group 2 Stock Stakes aboard high-class mare Fenway ($6.40) for his stepfather Lee Hope. Favourite May’s Dream finished third.
Shinn arrived at the Valley having already ridden for the Hopes at the Benalla Cup meeting during the day.
“Winning any big race for my family, or any race for that matter, means a lot to me because I know how hard they work behind the scenes,” Shinn said.
David Hayes unearthed another Caulfield Guineas contender in Stutt Stakes winner Sovereign Nation ($4.20), which he referred to as a “Christmas gift” from owner Gerry Harvey.
Michael Walker took the initiative in the race by sweeping to the front from the 600m mark when the pace slowed and the three-year-old colt toughed it out to the line.
“I know Gerry Harvey is keen if he pulls up well to run in the Guineas, and I’m even more keen to do it,” Hayes said.
Mornington trainer Matt Laurie pulled the upset of the night with $35 outsider Escado winning the JRA CUP courtesy of a gun front-running ride from Ben Melham.
Consistent stayer Magnapal finished a head second, while the $2.50 race favourite The United States could not make up enough ground off a slow pace.
Originally published as Buffering wins record third Moir Stakes
